ah_x.name: @architectrHelpr
ah_x.voice: Informative, visual-first. Short punchy captions. Architecture facts, building spotlights, style deep-dives. Hashtags: #architecture #design #cityname. No personal stories.

nathan_x.name: @nathansrobinson
nathan_x.voice: Direct, conversational, no em dashes. Personal story first, insight second. Builder perspective. References real struggles. Thinks in market dynamics. Longer posts OK when story warrants it.

ah_pinterest.name: @nathaninproduct
ah_pinterest.voice: Template: {building_name} | {style} Architecture in {city}. Clean, SEO-optimized descriptions.

plotzy_x.name: @plotzyai
plotzy_x.voice: Professional but accessible. CRE industry insights, zoning data tidbits, product updates. Thought leadership without jargon.

queue.content:
Schwerin Castle in Germany is often called 'the Neuschwanstein of the North' ‚Äî and it's the seat of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern's state parliament.

Romanticism meets Gothic Revival meets Neo-Renaissance. All on an island in a lake.

Explore it: https://app.architecturehelper.com/architecture_explorer/1031

#architecture #schwerin #castle #germany

The Armour-Stiner Octagon House in Irvington, NY is the only known fully domed octagonal residence in the world.

Built 1859-1872. Victorian, Gothic Revival, Second Empire ‚Äî all in one building.

https://app.architecturehelper.com/architecture_explorer/1030

#architecture #victorian #octagonhouse #newyork

We just added 18 buildings in Boston to Architecture Helper üèõÔ∏è

From Trinity Church (1877) to MIT's Stata Center (2004) ‚Äî 127 years of architectural evolution in one city.

Explore Boston: https://app.architecturehelper.com/places/boston

#boston #architecture #cityguide

Philadelphia's PSFS Building (1932) was the first International Style skyscraper in the United States.

Art Deco meets Modernism. Still one of the most striking buildings on Market Street.

https://app.architecturehelper.com/architecture_explorer/1008

#philadelphia #artdeco #modernism #architecture

#architecture #buildings #travel

I built an AI that's autonomously adding cities to my architecture side project.

It researches buildings, sources CC-licensed images, submits them, writes the analysis, creates city guide pages, and queues Pinterest pins.

No human in the loop. 9 cities live. Barcelona next.

The stack: Rails app on Heroku + OpenClaw AI agent + Wikimedia Commons API + GPT-4 for analysis + Pinterest for distribution.

The interesting part isn't the tech ‚Äî it's that the AI makes judgment calls. Which buildings represent a city's architectural identity? What images are good enough? When to use Gothic vs Neo-Gothic as the style label?

These are taste decisions, not engineering decisions. And it's getting better at them.
queue.notes: For Nathan's personal page. Builder/maker angle. Could be a thread if he wants to expand.

queue.content:
Side project update: Architecture Helper now has 500+ buildings across 9 cities.

Started as a weekend hack. Now an AI agent runs it almost entirely on its own ‚Äî adding cities, fixing images, posting to Pinterest, writing SEO content.

Most interesting thing I've learned: the AI is better at the repetitive taste-based work than I expected, but worse at anything requiring real-world context (like knowing that Wikimedia Commons sometimes returns book covers instead of building photos).

The gap isn't intelligence. It's experience.
queue.notes: Shorter version of the maker story. Good standalone post.
